questions.text: An obese man was posted for bariatric surgery. Which of the following is the inhalational agent of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Desflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice for this patient.

In obese individuals, the increased fat stores increase the volume of distribution for lipid-soluble drugs when compared to a lean individual of the same body weight. This increases the peripheral distribution of the lipid-soluble agents thus resulting in increased recovery time. There is an increase in the cardiac output in obese individuals that increases the early distribution of the drugs. Hence fat-soluble drugs should be administered based on the total body weight. Water-soluble agents like neuromuscular blockers have a smaller peripheral distribution that is minimally increased by body fat. Therefore, water-soluble agents are dosed based on the ideal body weight.

Among the commonly used inhalational anesthetics, desflurane is the least fat-soluble which leads to a faster recovery. Desflurane is also minimally metabolized by the liver, thereby reducing hepatotoxicity. 

Inhalational agent Blood-gas partition coefficient
Halothane 2.5
Isoflurane 1.4
Sevoflurane 0.65
Desflurane 0.45

Blood-gas partition co-efficient determines the solubility of the anesthetic agent in the blood. The higher the blood-gas partition coefficient, the higher will be the solubility of the anesthetic agent. This leads to its greater uptake by pulmonary circulation. The higher the uptake of the anesthetic agent, the higher the difference between the inspired and alveolar concentrations, which leads to a slower rate of induction and recovery. Desflurane has a very low blood:gas partition coefficient (0.42). Thus, the alveolar and blood concentrations rapidly rise to the level of inspired concentration, providing rapid induction of anesthesia and rapid recovery.

Other options:

Option A- Halothane is a high fat-soluble agent and can result in halothane hepatitis due to increased metabolism in obese individuals. Hence it is avoided.

Option C- Sevoflurane has a relatively higher fat solubility compared to desflurane.

Option D- Isoflurane has a higher fat-gas partition co-efficient resulting in increased recovery time from anesthesia.

questions.text: Anxious parents brought their infant to the pediatric outpatient with complaints of an abnormal increase in the size of his head. Investigations revealed hydrocephalus due to the vein of Galen malformation. Identify the great vein of Galen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The great vein of Galen is marked as '1' in the image given above.

The great cerebral vein (of Galen) is a short median vessel, formed by the joining of the internal cerebral veins. It then curves sharply up around the splenium of the corpus callosum and opens into the anterior end of the straight sinus, located along the junction between the falx and the tentorium cerebelli.

Clinical significance:

  • Vein of Galen aneurysmal malformations (VGAM) is the most common form of symptomatic cerebrovascular malformation in neonates and infants.
  • Vein of Galen malformation can result in hydrocephalus, heart failure, or rarely, hemorrhage.
  • There may be the absence of great vein of Galen in some congenital disorders.

questions.text: Which of the following complications is associated with bilateral adrenalectomy?
questions.solution:
Nelson’s syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumor is not possible.

The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases CRH. This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumor or the formation of a new one.

Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Excessive ACTH secretion
  • Corticotroph adenoma

Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain is performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.

The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

Option A: Sheehan’s syndrome refers to postpartum hypopituitarism that is caused by ischemic necrosis of the anterior pituitary as a result of severe postpartum hemorrhage.

Option B: Addison's disease occurs due to autoimmune destruction of adrenal glands.

Option C: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome refers to adrenal apoplexy that is caused by fulminant meningococcemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman undergoing treatment for pulmonary tuberculosis develops resistance to isoniazid. What is the most common mechanism by which this occurs?
questions.solution:
The most common mechanism of resistance to isoniazid (INH) in clinical isolates of Mycobacterium tuberculosis is by a mutation in the KatG gene.

Isoniazid (INH) is used as chemotherapy for drug-susceptible TB. It is given in combination with pyrazinamide, ethambutol, and rifampin. 

Isoniazid is not directly toxic to mycobacteria but gets activated to its toxic form by KatG, which is a catalase-peroxidase. A series of reactions occur which ultimately causes inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis, which leads to bacterial cell death.

Resistance to INH occurs by the following mechanisms:

  • Mutation of KatG - most common mechanism
  • Overexpression of inhA genes- confers a low level of resistance
  • Overexpression of ahpC
  • Induction of efflux pumps

Related Pearl: Drug resistance and the causative point mutations in M.tuberculosis

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: You are posted as an occupational health officer in an industry. You would perform a daily medical examination on the workers that are handling ________.
questions.solution:
Workers who handle irritant chemicals like dichromate require a daily medical examination.

A periodic medical examination is necessary when workers handle toxic or poisonous substances. This is done to recognize any early stages of diseases related to occupational origin. The frequency of the examination will depend on the type of occupational exposure. These periodical examinations may be supplemented with radiological and biological tests whenever necessary.

Industry Frequency of examination
Dichromate Daily
Lead, radium, toxic dyes Monthly
Most other exposure  Annually

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures. There is no history of weakness of any part of the body. A CT scan was done, and the image is given below. The characteristic sign depicted in the image is ______.

(MCA- middle cerebral artery)
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the CT image showing the bracket sign is suggestive of pericallosal lipoma. 

The most common site of lipoma in the brain is pericallosal region. Calcification at the periphery of the midline lipoma produces the characteristic bracket sign. Approximately 50% of patients present with seizures. Many cases are detected incidentally in utero by antenatal sonography.

Pericallosal lipomas can be grouped into two distinct types based on imaging:

  • Tubulonodular
  • Curvilinear

The tubulonodular variety is usually associated with more severe and extensive abnormalities and patients are symptomatic.

Other options:

Option B: The racing car sign refers to widely spaced lateral ventricles due to agenesis of the corpus callosum with intervening Probst bundles.

Option C: Hyperdense MCA sign- It refers to the hyperdense middle cerebral artery seen on non-enhanced CT images in acute stroke.

Option D: Dural tail sign: It refers to a linear, contrast-enhancing tail-like extension from the tumor, along the dura matter. It is most commonly seen in meningioma (present in about 60% of the cases).

questions.text: A young lady who had jumped from the fourth floor of her apartment building was brought to the casualty. CT pelvis revealed jumper's fracture. Which of the following best describes the fracture?

choices.text: Fracture of the dome of the acetabulum
Combination fracture of pubis and ilium
Bilateral fracture of both pubic rami
H or U shaped sacral fractures

questions.solution:
Jumper’s fracture is H or U-shaped fracture of the sacrum.

These are called jumper's or suicide jumper's fracture as they are seen in falls from height. There are two longitudinal fractures that run through the sacral foramina and a transverse fracture. The level of the transverse fracture line determines if it is H or U shaped. 

As these fractures pass through the sacral foramina, they can cause injury to the spinal cord and result in cauda equina syndrome.

questions.text: A farmer was diagnosed with brucellosis. Which of the following patterns of fever will be seen in this disease?
questions.solution:
Brucellosis is a bacterial zoonosis caused by Brucella sp which presents with undulant fever. It is referred to as undulant fever because of the rising and falling of fever like a wave (remittent fever). Patients may also have arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. 

Other options

Option A: Pel-Ebstein fever is seen in Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is characterized by fever lasting 3–10 days followed by afebrile periods of 3–10 days.

Option C: Relapsing fever is seen in infection with Borrelia recurrentis in which days of fever are followed by a several-day afebrile period and then relapse into additional days of fever. A similar picture is also seen in malaria.

Option D: Saddleback fever is seen in dengue.  Saddleback fever is defined as temperature >37.5°C  with defervescence of at least one day, followed by a second peak lasting at least one day.

questions.text: Todani classification system is used for the assessment of _______.
questions.solution:
Todani classification is used for the assessment of Choledochal cysts.

Other options:

Option C: Milwaukee classification is used to assess the sphincter of Oddi dysfunction.

Option D: Strasberg classification is used in bile duct injuries. It is based on the anatomical location of the injury.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby girl is being investigated for recurrent episodes of dermatitis. She develops blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight. Parents report pinkish discoloration of the child's diapers. Characteristic "monkey-like" facies, delayed eruption and reddish discoloration of teeth are noted on examination.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an 18-month-old baby with characteristic monkey-like facies, blisters over the face, hands, and feet on exposure to sunlight, reddish discolouration of teeth, erythrodontia, and pink stain in diapers are seen in congenital erythropoietic porphyria. 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria also known as Gunther's disease is autosomal recessive porphyria due to the uroporphyrinogen III synthase defect. It presents with non-immune hydrops in utero or shortly after birth. Severe cutaneous photosensitivity is present. Uroporphyrin I and coproporphyrin I accumulate in teeth, bone marrow, erythrocytes, plasma urine, and faeces.

Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers is seen. When illuminated with UV light, the teeth show a reddish fluorescence phenomenon known as erythrodontia (as shown in the image below).


Other options:

Option B: Porphyria cutanea tarda also presents as blistering photosensitivity but typically manifests in adults. Moreover, erythrodontia is not seen. It is the most common type of porphyria, which is caused by a deficiency of Uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase.

Option C: Erythropoietic protoporphyria presents as non-blistering photosensitivity, unlike in this case.

Option D: Acute intermittent porphyria presents with neurovisceral symptoms after puberty. It presents with abdominal pain and psychosis with no cutaneous features. It may be precipitated by drugs, decreased carbohydrate intake, and infections.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: A young man presents with burning micturition and frequent staining of undergarments with a purulent discharge. He admits to having unprotected sexual intercourse a week ago. On inspection, the following findings are seen. What is the most likely causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing swelling in the distal shaft of the penis known as bullhead clap are suggestive of acute urethritis. The most likely causative organism for acute urethritis in males is Neisseria gonorrhoeae. 

Urethritis is classified into two types:

  • Gonococcal urethritis - caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.
  • Non-gonococcal urethritis - caused by:
    • Chlamydia trachomatis (most common)
    • Ureaplasma urealyticum
    • Trichomonas vaginalis (rare)
    • Herpes simplex virus (rare)

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is the infection of gonococci to the urethra or other mucosal surfaces. The incubation period is 2-8 days. The major symptoms include purulent urethral discharge and dysuria. 

In males, the disease starts as acute urethritis. The patients may also have penile lymphangitis when the soft tissue inflammation is extensive. This infection may extend along the urethra to involve the prostate, seminal vesicles, and epididymis. 

In females, the initial infection involves the cervix uteri and urethra which may extend to Bartholin glands, endometrium, and fallopian tubes. Pelvic inflammatory disease and salpingitis may lead to sterility. Rarely peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation (Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome). 

The discharge is collected and subjected to Gram's stain which reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. Stuart's transport medium is used. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. Specifically, Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

Treatment includes ceftriaxone (250 mg, IM) single-dose + azithromycin 1 g PO, single-dose, or doxycycline 100 mg PO BD for 7 days. 

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: An infant presented with anemia. A blood test was performed where 0.36% saline was added to the blood sample. The control and test results are shown below. What is this test used for?

choices.text: Testing spheroidal red cell in spherocytosis
Red cell lysis for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria

questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked eye single tube red cell osmotic fragility test. It is a very useful screening tool for thalassemia, particularly in poor resource settings.

The principle is based on the decreased osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. The normal red blood cells lyse in a test tube with 0.36% saline solution. If this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will be visible. However, in the beta-thalassemia trait, due to decreased osmotic fragility, the cells do not lyse in 0.36% saline solution. Therefore, if this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will not be visible.

NESTROFT Inference Reason
Lines visible (negative) Normal Hemolysis has occurred
Lines not seen (positive) Thalassemia Stable RBC, unable to lyse

The image given below shows the NESTROFT.

Thalassemia is a group of hereditary disorders in which there is a reduced synthesis of one or more of the globin polypeptide chains.

The hematological findings in thalassemia are:

  • microcytic hypochromic anemia
  • raised unconjugated bilirubin
  • reticulocytosis
  • reduced MCV, MCH, and MCHC
  • decreased osmotic fragility
  • hemoglobin electrophoresis will show increased levels of HbF and HbA2 with markedly decreased levels of normal hemoglobin.

Other options:

Option A- Demonstration of sickling in sickle cell trait is done under reduced oxygen tension by sodium metabisulfite which is an oxygen-consuming reagent. The patients with sickle cell trait have no anemia and have normal-appearing red cells. They develop sickle cell crises in hypoxic conditions. 

Option C- Osmotic fragility test is helpful in testing the spheroidal nature of red cells in hereditary spherocytosis. In hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility is increased since spheroidal red cells lyse more readily in solutions of low salt concentrations. 

Option D- Red cell lysis in acidic pH of Ham's test is to demonstrate the presence of increased sensitivity of red blood cells, leucocytes, and platelets to complement in PNH.

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: The following pattern of erythema is characteristic of _____.
questions.solution:
The given image shows superficial fern-like erythema called arborescent or filigree burns or Lichtenberg's flowers resembling branches of a tree which is characteristic of lightning stroke injury.

Electrical burns may lead to the formation of vesicles or bullae, or lead to the destruction of skin and subcutaneous tissues.

The image below shows an electrical burn.

questions.text: A boy presents with complaints of intermittent low-grade fever and membrane over the left tonsil, which appeared insidiously. On examination of the oral cavity, the surgeon tried to remove the membrane, which came off easily revealing an irregular ulcer over the tonsil. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of low-grade fever, easily removable membrane over tonsil revealing irregular ulcers is suggestive of Vincent’s angina.

The condition presents with low-grade fever and sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. A throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, specifically Borrelia vincentii.

Other Options:

Option A: Diphtheria is slower in onset with less local discomfort. In the above case, the membrane is removed easily but in diphtheria, the membrane is adherent and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils, onto the soft palate, and is dirty grey in color. The smear and culture of the throat swab will reveal Corynebacterium diphtheriae.


Option C: In Infectious mononucleosis, pharyngitis is the most prominent sign, with an exudate resembling that of streptococcal pharyngitis. Both tonsils are very much enlarged, congested, and covered with an exudative membrane. There is marked local discomfort. Lymph nodes are enlarged in the posterior triangle of the neck along with splenomegaly. There is the failure of antibiotic treatment. A blood smear may show more than 50% lymphocytes, of which about 10% are atypical. Paul-Bunnell test will show high tires of heterophile antibody.

Option D: Aphthous ulcer are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They may involve any part of the oral cavity or oropharynx. Sometimes, it is solitary and may involve the tonsil and the pillars. It is very painful. 

Other differential diagnoses for membrane over the tonsil:

  • Membranous tonsillitis
  • Malignancy of tonsil
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Leukemia
  • Traumatic ulcer
  • Candidal infection of the tonsil

questions.text: Examination of a resected specimen of an ovarian mass reveals signet ring cells are seen as shown below. Which of the following conditions is this associated with?
questions.solution:
Signet ring cells are seen in Krukenberg tumor.

A Krukenberg tumor is an ovarian malignancy that metastasized from a primary site, most commonly from the stomach (70%). Carcinomas of the colon, appendix, and breast (mainly invasive lobular carcinoma) are the next most common primary sites.

The route of spread may be:

  • Lymphatic
  • Hematogenous
  • Transcoelomic

They are usually bilateral and have a smooth surface with a waxy consistency. They retain the shape of a normal ovary.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a sad mood, anhedonia, and decreased sleep. He further reports that he believes that everything is coming to an end. He feels his organs are rotting. Additionally, he believes he has a disease that can spread and kill all humans on the planet, and he attempted suicide to prevent this from happening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Cotard syndrome.

Cotard syndrome or delire de negation or nihilistic delusion disorder: Patients complain that they have lost all their possessions, status, their entire being, and even their internal organs. They also feel that the world has reduced to nothingness. They might believe that they are dead and stop eating. It is commonly seen in patients with severe depression.

Other options:

Option A: In Fregoli Syndrome, the patients have a delusion that the familiar person can assume the appearance of (or disguised as) strangers. 

Option B: In Capgras syndrome (illusion des copies), the patients believe that their family members or other familiar people have been replaced by identical-looking imposters.

Option D: In Othello syndrome, the patient has delusions, which are predominantly jealousy and infidelity involving the spouse. This syndrome is named after the character in Shakespeare's play. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A study was conducted to find the factors that regulate stomach emptying. Which of the following factors are less of a trigger on enterogastric inhibitory reflex causing inhibition in stomach emptying?
questions.solution:
Enterogastric inhibitory reflexes are sensitive to the presence of acidic chyme in the duodenum, not alkaline. 

As the pH of the chyme fall in the duodenum, the enterogastric inhibitory reflexes block the further release of acidic stomach contents into the duodenum. This continues until the duodenal chyme gets neutralized by pancreatic acid and other secretions.

When the food enters the duodenum, multiple reflexes are initiated from the duodenal wall which pass back to the stomach. These reflexes slow or stop the stomach emptying if the volume of the chyme in the duodenum becomes too much. These reflexes are called enterogastric reflexes.

This enterogastric inhibitory reflex can be initiated by the following triggers:

  • Presence of irritants and acids in duodenal chyme (most sensitive factor)
  • Amount of chyme
  • Distension of duodenum 
  • Rapid entry of hypertonic or hypotonic fluids into the duodenum
  • Presence of breakdown products of protein digestion and sometimes fat
  • The osmolality of the chyme

Enterogastric reflexes are mediated by:

  • Enteric nervous system from the gut wall
  • Extrinsic nerves to the prevertebral sympathetic ganglia and back through the sympathetic nerve fibers to the stomach
  • Vagus nerves

questions.text: The electrocardiograph of a neonate, presenting with the following facial rash, is suggestive of a complete heart block. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given findings of a periorbital rash with ECG findings of a complete heart block are suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus. It is most likely to be associated with anti-Ro antibodies.

Neonatal lupus results from the passive transfer of maternal IgG autoantibodies (anti-Ro and anti-La) to the fetus. Hence, mothers with a known history of SLE or those who are positive for autoantibodies should undergo screening with fetal echocardiography. Detection of anti-Ro antibodies in a newborn is specific for neonatal lupus syndrome.

Clinical manifestations of neonatal lupus include a characteristic annular or macular rash typically affecting the face (especially the periorbital area), trunk, and scalp. The rash typically appears within the first 6 weeks of life after exposure to ultraviolet light and may last for 3-4 months.

The most feared complication is congenital heart block. Conduction system abnormalities range from prolongation of the PR interval to complete heart block. In severe cases, they can develop progressive cardiomyopathy. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age. Other noncardiac features include hepatitis, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Treatment options include corticosteroids (dexamethasone or betamethasone), intravenous immunoglobulins, plasmapheresis, hydroxychloroquine, and terbutaline, which are given to pregnant women with anti-Ro or anti-La antibodies to prevent occurrence or progression of fetal cardiac abnormalities. Treatment for neonates is directed at specific organ involvement. With cardiac pacing, children with conduction system disease in the absence of cardiomyopathy have an excellent prognosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Serology for rubella antibodies is done to confirm congenital rubella syndrome, which can have heart defects (most commonly patent ductus arteriosus). However, other features of the syndrome, like sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, and cataracts, are not present in this patient.

The given image shows a blueberry muffin rash seen in congenital rubella syndrome:

 

Option B: Serology for anti-treponemal antibodies is done to confirm congenital syphilis. Heart block and periorbital rash are not the features of congenital syphilis. In congenital syphilis, the maculopapular rash is characteristically present on the palms and soles. There will be hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes.

The given image shows maculopapular rash in congenital syphilis involving the soles:

 

Option C: Serology for anti-dsDNA antibodies is a highly specific test to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Features of SLE include malar rash, arthralgia, serositis, etc. These antibodies will be present in the mother but not in the baby.

The given image shows malar rash in SLE:

questions.text: A 36-year-old pregnant lady presents in her first trimester for a check-up. She mentions that she has a family history of the condition shown in the images below. Which of the following  can be used to screen for the condition during this visit?
questions.solution:
The images showing a child with oblique palpebral fissures, a depressed nasal bridge, and a single palmar crease are suggestive of Down's syndrome (Trisomy 21). Nuchal translucency (NT) is used to screen for it during the first trimester. 

Nuchal translucency is the maximum thickness of the translucent area between the skin and soft tissue over the fetal spine at the back of the neck. When the NT measurement is increased, it is a marker for fetal aneuploidy and struc­tural anomalies.

Combined first-trimester screening consists of serum human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG), pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A), and the measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT) on ultrasound. It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks of gestation.

In fetal Down syndrome, the first-trimester hCG level is increased, PAPP-A level is decreased, and nuchal translucency thickness is increased.

The ultrasound image below shows increased NT thickness and absent nasal bone of a fetus with Trisomy 21 at 11 weeks gestation:


Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) and unconjugated estriol are measured in the second trimester as part of the triple screening test. Inhibin A is measured as part of the quadruple screening test.

The screening test results associated with trisomy 21 are summarized in the table below:

Combined 1st trimester test Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test (2nd trimester)
Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased
PAPP-A decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
NT increased MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased
    Serum inhibin increased

Related Pearl: Prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome

  • USG findings
    • Intrauterine growth retardation (so decreased blood flow)
    • Choroid plexus cysts
    • Increased nuchal translucency >3 mm
    • Hypoplastic nasal bone
    • Congenital heart defects
    • Increased intestinal echogenicity
    • Duodenal atresia
  • Maternal serum markers
    • Decreased: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP), unconjugated estriol, pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
    • Increased: Human chorionic gonadotrophin (HCG), inhibin, neutrophil alkaline phosphatase
  • Amniocentesis: 14th-18th week of pregnancy
  • Chorionic villus sampling
    • 10th to 12th week of pregnancy: Gives the diagnosis in the first trimester

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect about Eale's disease?

choices.text: Causes gradual painful loss of vision

questions.solution:
Eale's disease causes sudden, painless loss of vision. It does not cause a gradual, painful loss of vision.

Eales disease is an idiopathic occlusive peripheral periphlebitis. Tubercular etiology is implicated. There are 3 stages of this disease: inflammatory, occlusive, and retinal neovascular stage.

Symptoms include floaters or sudden, painless loss of vision due to vitreous hemorrhage. 

Diagnosis is made when fundoscopy reveals the following features:

  • Peripheral periphlebitis- perivascular sheathing, superficial retinal hemorrhages are seen in the inflammatory stage.
  • Occlusion of the involved vessels in the occlusive stage.
  • Neovascularization and recurrent vitreous hemorrhage may occur at the junction of perfused and non-perfused retina in the retinal neovascular stage. 
  • Macular involvement may occur.

Investigations should be performed to rule out other causes of vasculitis (e.g. sarcoidosis, tuberculosis) and peripheral retinal neovascularization (e.g. hemoglobinopathies). Fluorescein angiography will identify vasculitis and the areas of non-perfusion.

Medical management includes oral and topical steroids given during the stage of inflammation. Anti-tubercular therapy is also recommended in some cases. Surgical management includes laser photocoagulation used in the stage of neovascularization. Vitrectomy is done if there is persistent vitreous hemorrhage, tractional retinal detachment, or macular epiretinal membrane.

Complications include tractional retinal detachment, macular epiretinal membrane, neovascular glaucoma, rubeosis iridis, and cataract. The visual prognosis is good in the majority of cases.
